item.description:
Standard payment flow for a regular credit card transaction.

Make sure your Tuna accont has an active credit card flow.

If the flow is not set to capture the transaction automatically you'll need to call the capture method after calling init.

--header "Tuna-AppToken: af4f0bc5-" \
--header "Tuna-Session: R7XgGS3RMNdLXazJVcuU=" \
--header "Tuna-Forward-To: https://postman-echo.com/post" \  
--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
--data-raw '{
	"Card": {

}'

item.description:
This set of APIs is intended for customers that use solely out credit card vault product(tokenization api).

Creating a session is the first step as a sessionid is always needed.

Then you can create and manage credit card tokens.

The proxy method can be used to send requests to PCI entities through Tuna.

We'll replace the token with the credit card data and send you the reponse back.

item.name: 3DS
3DS using pure js

request.description:
First step is generating a new session.

The sessionId will be stored into a variable that's going to be used by the other requests in this collection(that need a sessionId).

item.description:
This example uses pure js, as you would write yourself without using tuna.js.

Generate the tuna sessionid using the request below, then paste it and input credit card data at our [example form](https://storage.googleapis.com/tuna-statics/3dsUtil/3DSSamples/TokenWithPureJS-InitWithPostman/index.html).

This sessionid will contain a random orderid(named partneruniqueid at Tuna), this id locks this session to it, and it will be used by tuna.js when it automatically performs the payment init calls.

At the example form linked above, after pasting the sessionid onto it and clicking the button, I'll be shown the result of Tuna's [token api generate method](https://dev.tuna.uy/api/token#operation/Generate). You'll need to grab a few values from the response for the second and last step(init):

``` json
 "tokenData": {
        "token": "ct_****************************j0",

 ```

``` json
 "authenticationInformation": {
            "referenceId": "a332cece-fc33-4257-8a69-6adfefa7c0ab",
            "transactionId": "7187126538266544604970"
        },

 ```

Remember you can use 3DS for credit or debit transactions, choose the init script accordingly.

item.name: 3DS using tuna.js for tokenization

request.description:
First step is generating a new session.

item.description:
Using tuna.js makes it easier to use Tuna for 3DS purchases.

Generate the tuna sessionid using the request below, then paste it at our [example form](https://storage.googleapis.com/tuna-statics/3dsUtil/3DSSamples/TokenWithTunaJS-InitWithPostman/index.html).

This sessionid will contain a random orderid(named partneruniqueid at Tuna), this id locks this session to it, and it will be used by tuna.js when it automatically performs the payment init calls.

At the example form linked above, after pasting the sessionid onto it and clicking the button, I'll be shown the result of Tuna's [token api generate method](https://dev.tuna.uy/api/token#operation/Generate), which tuna.js conviniently calls for you. You'll need to grab a few values from the response for the second and last step(init):

``` json
 "tokenData": {
        "token": "ct_****************************j0",

 ```

``` json
 "authenticationInformation": {
            "referenceId": "a332cece-fc33-4257-8a69-6adfefa7c0ab",
            "transactionId": "7187126538266544604970"
        },

 ```

Remember you can use 3DS for credit or debit transactions, choose the init script accordingly.

item.name: 3DS using tuna.js for all interactions

request.description:
First step is generating a new session.

The sessionId will be stored into a variable that's going to be used by the other requests in this collection(that need a sessionId).

item.description:
Using tuna.js makes it easier to use Tuna for 3DS purchases.

Generate the tuna sessionid using the request below, then paste it at our [example form](https://storage.googleapis.com/tuna-statics/3dsUtil/3DSSamples/TokenWithTunaJS-InitWithTunaJS/index.html).

This sessionid will contain a random orderid(named partneruniqueid at Tuna), this id locks this session to it, and it will be used by tuna.js when it automatically performs the payment init calls.

At this example, tuna.js takes care of everthing: rendering the credit card fields, tokenization and making the purchase, all at the frontend application. In a real world scenario your backend application would have to call our [status api](https://dev.tuna.uy/api/payment#operation/Status) to be sure the information coming from the frontend is trustworthy.

item.name: 3DS with manual tokenization

request.description:
First step is generating a new session.

The sessionId will be stored into a variable that's going to be used by the other requests in this collection(that need a sessionId).

item.description:
This example uses pure js, as you would write yourself without using tuna.js.

Generate the tuna sessionid using the request below, then paste it and input credit card data at our [example form](https://storage.googleapis.com/tuna-statics/3dsUtil/3DSSamples/TokenWithPureJS-InitWithPostman/index.html).

This sessionid will contain a random orderid(named partneruniqueid at Tuna), this id locks this session to it, and it will be used by tuna.js when it automatically performs the payment init calls.

At the example form linked above, after pasting the sessionid onto it and clicking the button, I'll be shown the result of Tuna's [token api generate method](https://dev.tuna.uy/api/token#operation/Generate). You'll need to grab a few values from the response for the second and last step(init):

``` json
 "tokenData": {
        "token": "ct_****************************j0",

 ```

``` json
 "authenticationInformation": {
            "referenceId": "a332cece-fc33-4257-8a69-6adfefa7c0ab",
            "transactionId": "7187126538266544604970"
        },

 ```

Remember you can use 3DS for credit or debit transactions, choose the init script accordingly.

Please check the descriptions at each sub-folder.

Also check out our [https://github.com/tuna-software/3DSSamples](https://github.com/tuna-software/3DSSamples) with the source code of the html test forms and a node application that serves as an example for a backend application.

### Test Credit Cards

Use the card number specified in the test with the card expiration date set to the month of January and the current year plus three. For example, for 2025, use 2028. You also need the minimum required fields for an order.

#### Frictionless Authentication Is Successful

This test verifies that successful frictionless authentication of the cardholder by the card issuer works correctly.

| **Card Type** | **Test Card Number** |
| --- | --- |
|  | **3-D Secure 2.1.0** |
| American ExpressCard Type = 003 |  |
| Cartes Bancaires MastercardCard Type = 036 | 52000000 0000 3001 |
| Cartes Bancaires VisaCard Type = 036 | 40000000 0000 3006 |
| Diners ClubCard Type = 005 |  |
| DiscoverCard Type = 004 |  |
| EFTPOS MastercardCard Type = 002 | 52000000 0000 5170 |
| EFTPOS VisaCard Type = 001 | 40000000 0000 5126 |
| EloCard Type = 054 |  |
| ITMX VisaCard Type = 001 | 46320821 0000 0005 |
| ITMX MastercardCard Type = 002 | 55775501 2100 0000 |
| JCB J/SecureCard Type = 007 |  |
| mada MastercardCard Type = 060 |  |
| mada VisaCard Type = 060 |  |
| MastercardCard Type = 002 |  |
| China UnionPayCard Type = 062 | 62000100 0020 0000 |
| VisaCard Type = 001 |  |

#### Frictionless Authentication Is Unsuccessful

#### Stand-In Frictionless Authentication is Attempted

This test verifies how your system reacts when the cardholder is enrolled in 3-D Secure but the card issuer does not support 3-D Secure, requiring a stand-in authentication experience.

| China UnionPayCard Type = 062 | 62000100 0000 0020 |
| VisaCard Type = 001 |  |

#### Frictionless Authentication Is Unavailable

This test verifies how your system behaves when authentication is unavailable at the time of the transaction.

## Card Numbers

#### Step-Up Authentication Is Successful

This test verifies how your system reacts to a successful step-up (or challenge) authentication transaction.

item.description:
Standard payment flow for a regular PIX transaction.

Make sure your Tuna accont has an active PIX flow.

item.name: Wallets
Google Pay
item.description:
Follow [our documentation](https://dev.tuna.uy/services/googlepay/) for information regarding using Google Pay at Tuna.

We recommend using out [javacript plugin](https://dev.tuna.uy/plugins/javascript#using-google-pay) for a quicker integration.

Check our [Google Pay example form](https://storage.googleapis.com/tuna-statics/walletPaymentSamples/GooglePaySample.html) out.

item.name: Apple Pay
item.description:
Follow [our documentation](https://dev.tuna.uy/plugins/javascript#using-apple-pay) for information regarding using Apple Pay at Tuna.

We recommend using out [javacript plugin](https://dev.tuna.uy/plugins/javascript#using-google-pay) for a quicker integration.

Check our [Apple Pay example form](https://checkout.tunagateway.com/extra/applePay.html) out.

At Tuna, proprietary wallets like Nupay, Mercado Pago and PayPal are considered "external" payment methods and therefore we use payment method type "9" for them.

If you have more than one of these wallets, you need to create separated flows for them at Tuna, and to differentiate them you can use one of init's generic dicctionaries.

In these examples we've used PaymentMethod.Data.ExternalMethodType.

Apple Pay and Google Pay are not considered external since they will always be processed in a transparent fashion. The users merely pick the cards from their wallets using the mandatory client side scripts, then you need to send Tuna their encrypted tokens signaling that the Token provider is either "GooglePay" or "ApplePay.
